subject: RE: [junit] Question on assertEquals()
msgSnippet: ... It s not necessary, because Sets and Maps already have to implement equals in that way - so you can use the ordinary assertEquals. The Junit-Addons method
messageBody:
> JUnit-Addons (junit-addons.sourceforge.net) does have a ListAssert
> that asserts that two lists contain the same elements (regardless of
> order). Unfortunately, it doesn't have similar assertions for Sets or
> Maps

It's not necessary, because Sets and Maps already have to implement equals
in that way - so you can use the ordinary assertEquals. The Junit-Addons
method is only useful if you don't care about the order of elements, because
Lists equals methods have to care about order.

Take care, Ilja
